Comments_List: I learned a greater knowledge of Russian grand strategy, and how Russian/Soviet/post-Soviet foreign policy is not very different.
Better understanding of long-term trends in Russian foreign policy.

Historical cases of Russian foreign policy, challenges and opportunities for Russian foreign policy throughout the centuries, changes in dynamics of the challenges due to globalisation and ideological developments. Understanding of geographic, bureaucratic, domestic and international constraints.
Analyzing policy-making decisions from Moscow's perspective, and better understanding the Russian's decision-making process over the course of the last 200+ years.

Through this course, I learned about Russias previous diplomatic decision-makings in the face of critical moments from the early 19th century to today. The course convinced me that some aspects of Russian diplomacy have continuity for more than two centuries, so the historical understandings are helpful in analyzing the current challenges regarding Russian foreign relations.

The course is well thought out, it covers a number of topics. It is not taught from a very ideological lens, there's ample room to disagree. The weakness is that the discussion is tricky with 18 people, and the quality of presentations varies. Some are good, some not so good. Perhaps a debate format would be better. The reading list is mostly clippings from secondary sources, so I never felt like I read works about Russian foreign policy.
The course is fantastic and Prof. Graham is a great instructor.
Main strengths are a presentation by a pair of students each week (facilitates broader understanding and academic collaboration) and the breadth of the course.

Strengths: well-structured, interesting readings, coursework is adequate.
Weaknesses: none.

The strengths included the beginning lecture portion of the class that presented the background context, the discussions that the presentations stimulated, and the consideration of the policy-making decisions from Moscow's point of view.

Strength: The course covered not only the west side of Russia (relations with Europe and the U.S.) but also the south and east sides (those with Central and East Asia), which is compatible with Russias growing diplomatic interest in Asia in the 21st century. / Weakness: Nothing
Russia is much in the news now, and I think if you want to understand the motivations, it is good.
Yes, this is a valuable course.
I highly recommend this course to the students interested in the current Russian foreign affairs as well as those who would like to study Russian modern history.
